articles.headline: Greek Statue Travels Again, but Not to Greece
articles.snippet: The British Museum plunged itself into a geopolitical tempest with the loan of one of the famous Elgin marbles of Greece to the Hermitage.
articles.abstract: The British Museum plunged itself into a geopolitical tempest with the loan of one of the famous Elgin marbles of Greece to the Hermitage.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Museum plunged itself into a geopolitical tempest on Friday, lending one of the most disputed Greek artifacts to Russia’s State Hermitage Museum in a surprise arrangement that outraged Greece.

articles.headline: Rolling Stone Cites Doubts on Its Story of University of Virginia Rape
articles.snippet: The magazine acknowledged “discrepancies” in an article that described a gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity.
articles.abstract: The magazine acknowledged “discrepancies” in an article that described a gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — An account of sexual assault in Rolling Stone magazine that shook the University of Virginia and horrified readers showed signs of crumbling on Friday as the magazine admitted to doubts about its report of a premeditated gang rape at a fraternity party and the fraternity issued its first rebuttal of some details.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: A Liability Risk for Airbnb Hosts
articles.snippet: The home-sharing business now has secondary coverage, which kicks in after a homeowner’s primary insurance.
articles.abstract: The home-sharing business now has secondary coverage, which kicks in after a homeowner’s primary insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, Uber and Airbnb have come to be known as leaders of something called the sharing economy.

articles.headline: U.S. to Continue Racial, Ethnic Profiling in Border Policy
articles.snippet: Under new rules to be issued by the White House, federal agents can still consider race and ethnicity when stopping people at airports and immigration checkpoints, officials said.
articles.abstract: Under new rules to be issued by the White House, federal agents can still consider race and ethnicity when stopping people at airports and immigration checkpoints, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration will soon issue new rules curtailing the use of profiling, but federal agents will still be allowed to consider race and ethnicity when stopping people at airports, border crossings and immigration checkpoints, according to several government officials.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Brighter Economy Raises Odds of Action in Congress
articles.snippet: An improving labor market, broad economic growth and a falling federal budget deficit are brightening the prospect of bipartisan cooperation next year.
articles.abstract: An improving labor market, broad economic growth and a falling federal budget deficit are brightening the prospect of bipartisan cooperation next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A strikingly improving labor market, coupled with broad economic growth and a falling federal budget deficit, is improving the prospects of bipartisan cooperation next year — if Republicans and Democrats can seize on easing fiscal pressures to give both sides some of their wish lists.

articles.headline: Power Savings of Smart Meters Prove Slow to Materialize
articles.snippet: Modern power meters are meant to talk directly to power companies, their customers and their customers’ dishwashers, but they have yet to live up to their potential.
articles.abstract: Modern power meters are meant to talk directly to power companies, their customers and their customers’ dishwashers, but they have yet to live up to their potential.
articles.lead_paragraph: The end is in sight for the meter reader, who each month faithfully tramps through the flower beds or into the basement, flashlight and clipboard in hand, to record electricity use.

articles.headline: After Jobs Report, Obama Takes a Little Credit
articles.snippet: The recovery has gained enough traction, White House officials say, that President Obama can make a robust case for how the accelerating job growth is likely to translate into higher wages.
articles.abstract: The recovery has gained enough traction, White House officials say, that President Obama can make a robust case for how the accelerating job growth is likely to translate into higher wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before introducing his nominee to fill the job of defense secretary, President Obama took a moment on Friday to celebrate the creation of 321,000 additional jobs in November. It was as close to a victory lap on the economy that Mr. Obama has taken.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s History as First Lady: Powerful, but Not Always Deft
articles.snippet: The release of candid interviews of Clinton administration aides shows Hillary Rodham Clinton’s years as first lady were rife with explosive and often politically clumsy dealings.
articles.abstract: The release of candid interviews of Clinton administration aides shows Hillary Rodham Clinton’s years as first lady were rife with explosive and often politically clumsy dealings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a young lawyer for the Watergate committee in the 1970s, Hillary Rodham caught a ride home one night with her boss, Bernard Nussbaum. Sitting in the car before going inside, she told him she wanted to introduce him to her boyfriend. “Bernie,” she said, “he’s going to be president of the United States.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Police Killings Reveal Chasms Between Races
articles.snippet: The recent high-profile deaths of black people at the hands of police officers have exposed sharp differences about race relations in unexpected and often uncomfortable ways.
articles.abstract: The recent high-profile deaths of black people at the hands of police officers have exposed sharp differences about race relations in unexpected and often uncomfortable ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the decade that Ashley Bernaugh, who is white, has been with her black husband, her family in Indiana has been so smitten with him that she teases them that they love him more than her.

articles.headline: 2 Hostages Killed in Yemen as U.S. Rescue Effort Fails
articles.snippet: Luke Somers, a journalist, and Pierre Korkie, a teacher, were being held by Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen when they died during a raid by United States commandos Saturday, officials said.
articles.abstract: Luke Somers, a journalist, and Pierre Korkie, a teacher, were being held by Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen when they died during a raid by United States commandos Saturday, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — United States commandos stormed a village in southern Yemen early Saturday in an effort to free an American photojournalist held hostage by Al Qaeda, but the raid ended in tragedy, with the kidnappers killing the American and a South African held with him, United States officials said.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: How Wall Street Bent Steel
articles.snippet: The division of Timken, a family-controlled company, into separate companies making bearings and steel has brought anxiety to its Ohio hometown.
articles.abstract: The division of Timken, a family-controlled company, into separate companies making bearings and steel has brought anxiety to its Ohio hometown.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chain of events that’s put everyone in Canton, Ohio, on edge, from steelworkers and machine tool makers to the school superintendent and, above all, the scion who runs this small city’s biggest company, started with a few keystrokes 2,400 miles away in a bland suburban office building in San Diego.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Kept U.S. Inquiry Quiet
articles.snippet: Vertical Capital forbade its marketing chief to reveal that its founder and related brokerage firm were the subject of a securities investigation.
articles.abstract: Vertical Capital forbade its marketing chief to reveal that its founder and related brokerage firm were the subject of a securities investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the volatile world of high finance, hedge funds come and hedge funds go. So there was little fanfare last week, apart from a few upset investors, when Vertical Capital, with $1.4 billion under management, suddenly announced it was unwinding its $400 million hedge fund operation.

articles.headline: Energy Firms in Secretive Alliance With Attorneys General
articles.snippet: Republican attorneys general have formed an unprecedented, secretive alliance with some of the nation’s top energy producers to push back against the Obama regulatory agenda, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
articles.abstract: Republican attorneys general have formed an unprecedented, secretive alliance with some of the nation’s top energy producers to push back against the Obama regulatory agenda, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: The letter to the Environmental Protection Agency from Attorney General Scott Pruitt of Oklahoma carried a blunt accusation: Federal regulators were grossly overestimating the amount of air pollution caused by energy companies drilling new natural gas wells in his state.

articles.headline: As Ebola Rages, Poor Planning Thwarts Efforts
articles.snippet: Aid officials in Sierra Leone say weak coordination among aid groups, government mismanagement and glaring inefficiencies are costing countless lives.
articles.abstract: Aid officials in Sierra Leone say weak coordination among aid groups, government mismanagement and glaring inefficiencies are costing countless lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: KERRY TOWN, Sierra Leone — On a freshly cleared hillside outside the capital, where the trees have been chopped down and replaced with acres of smooth gravel, the new Ebola treatment center seems to have everything. There are racks of clean pink scrubs and white latex boots, bathrooms that smell like Ajax, solar-powered lights, a pharmacy tent, even a thatch-roofed hut to relax in.

articles.headline: Forget the Hounds. As Foxes Creep In, Britons Call the Sniper.
articles.snippet: “They may appear cuddly and romantic, but foxes are also a pest and a menace,” Mayor Boris Johnson said. Some in London, however, are working to save the animals from harm.
articles.abstract: “They may appear cuddly and romantic, but foxes are also a pest and a menace,” Mayor Boris Johnson said. Some in London, however, are working to save the animals from harm.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sniper arrived at sunset with infrared binoculars and a silencer in his tennis bag. He set up his .22-caliber rifle in the back of a Victorian townhouse, cracked open the glass door and pointed the shrouded barrel toward the far corner of the narrow garden. Then he waited, his right eye glued to the scope, as the last light leaked away.

articles.headline: Uruguay Accepts 6 Detainees Held at Guantánamo
articles.snippet: The transfer announced by the Defense Department was the largest single group of inmates to leave the prison in Cuba since 2009.
articles.abstract: The transfer announced by the Defense Department was the largest single group of inmates to leave the prison in Cuba since 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States transferred six detainees from the Guantánamo Bay prison to Uruguay this weekend, the Defense Department announced early Sunday. It was the largest single group of inmates to depart the wartime prison in Cuba since 2009, and the first to be resettled in South America.

articles.headline: Hollywood Tracks Social Media Chatter to Target Hit Films
articles.snippet: Studios are embracing data tools like PreAct, which use algorithms to analyze data from social media months or more before a film opens.
articles.abstract: Studios are embracing data tools like PreAct, which use algorithms to analyze data from social media months or more before a film opens.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Hollywood has long relied on consumer surveys to answer a question about soon-to-arrive movies: To what degree have marketing materials made a film a must-see?

articles.headline: Obama’s Net Neutrality Bid Divides Civil Rights Groups
articles.snippet: The vision for regulation of the Internet has met with opposition from the N.A.A.C.P. and the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, while other civil rights groups support treating Internet access as an essential service.
articles.abstract: The vision for regulation of the Internet has met with opposition from the N.A.A.C.P. and the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, while other civil rights groups support treating Internet access as an essential service.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama laid out his vision for strict regulation of Internet access last month, he was voicing views thought to be held by many at the most liberal end of the Democratic Party.

articles.headline: Paid to Promote Eye Drug, and Prescribing It Widely
articles.snippet: Half of the 20 doctors who received the most money from Genentech to promote its drug Lucentis in 2013 were among the highest users of the drug in 2012, a federal database shows.
articles.abstract: Half of the 20 doctors who received the most money from Genentech to promote its drug Lucentis in 2013 were among the highest users of the drug in 2012, a federal database shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the drug maker Genentech introduced a major product in 2006, it found itself in an awkward position: persuading eye doctors to start using its new more expensive drug instead of a popular cheaper version that the company already sold.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Rolling Stone Tries to Regroup After Campus Rape Article Is Disputed
articles.snippet: After The Washington Post raised doubts on its story of rape at the University of Virginia, Rolling Stone is weighing how to report on people who have suffered violence or trauma.
articles.abstract: After The Washington Post raised doubts on its story of rape at the University of Virginia, Rolling Stone is weighing how to report on people who have suffered violence or trauma.
articles.lead_paragraph: Started nearly a half-century ago as a chronicle of 1960s counterculture, Rolling Stone established its journalistic credibility with provocative coverage of politics and current affairs.

articles.headline: Revolt at the New New Republic
articles.snippet: Chris Hughes, a Facebook founder, purchased The New Republic magazine in 2012 praising its journalistic history, but recent decisions there have led to a walkout by several staff members.
articles.abstract: Chris Hughes, a Facebook founder, purchased The New Republic magazine in 2012 praising its journalistic history, but recent decisions there have led to a walkout by several staff members.
articles.lead_paragraph: In retrospect, last week’s meltdown at The New Republic should have been easy to predict.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: At 6, Awaiting Hostage’s Release. After 8, Learning That He’s Dead.
articles.snippet: Hours from being released by Qaeda abductors in Yemen, in return for a $200,000 ransom arranged by his family and a charity group, Pierre Korkie of South Africa was killed as Navy SEALs tried to rescue his American cellmate.
articles.abstract: Hours from being released by Qaeda abductors in Yemen, in return for a $200,000 ransom arranged by his family and a charity group, Pierre Korkie of South Africa was killed as Navy SEALs tried to rescue his American cellmate.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For 18 months, a group of civilians in South Africa worked to accomplish what their government had been unable to do: negotiate the release of a South African couple held by Al Qaeda in the lawless desert of southern Yemen.

articles.headline: Merck in $8.4 Billion Deal for Cubist, Big Maker of Antibiotics
articles.snippet: The deal will give Merck, the second-largest American drug maker after Pfizer, control of the largest antibiotics company, and deepen its ties with hospitals.
articles.abstract: The deal will give Merck, the second-largest American drug maker after Pfizer, control of the largest antibiotics company, and deepen its ties with hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deal making in the health care industry has been booming all year, with medical technology companies and cosmetic drug makers changing hands at rich premiums.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Donors Seek to Anoint a 2016 Nominee Early
articles.snippet: They fear being split into competing camps and raising hundreds of millions of dollars for a bloody primary that will injure the eventual nominee.
articles.abstract: They fear being split into competing camps and raising hundreds of millions of dollars for a bloody primary that will injure the eventual nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dozens of the Republican Party’s leading presidential donors and fund-raisers have begun privately discussing how to clear the field for a single establishment candidate to carry the party’s banner in 2016, fearing that a prolonged primary would bolster Hillary Rodham Clinton, the likely Democratic candidate.
